ast.name: sprite sheet
ast.comment: Library to work with sprite sheets and animate them.

body.text: Initializes the library with the given `board`.
Creates a sprite that uses the image at the given position (`row`, `column`) in the sheet identified by `sheet id`.
Sets the left and top margins in pixels.
Sets the gaps between columns and rows in pixels.
Draws the sprite cells cut lines. Useful for debugging.
This library allows to work with sprite sheets organized in a regular array. Packaging many sprites into a single image is a very efficient way of dealing with large number of sprites.
Let's start by creating a board, we will need it for the demo.
Let's also create a picture that contains numbers that we will use as our sprite sheet.
## Initialization
Call `initialize` with the board that will hold the sprites.
Each sprite sheet has to be registered with a unique id. The `sheet id` will be used in other calls to identify that sprite sheet. You can register multiple sprite sheets with this library.
Did you get the number of columns, rows correctly? You can use the `draw grid` functionality to check where the sprites are cut.
## Create sprite
Call `create sprite` to create a picture sprite that displays the sprite at a particular row and column. The cells are indexed as follows:
(rows, 1) (rows, 2)  ... (rows, columns)
## Change the picture
You can use the `set sprite picture` action to dynamically change which sprite cell is displayed on a sprite created by `create sprite`.
## Animations
By changing the picture of a sprite, you can create animated characters. This is a classic technique used in game to create animations at a low computational cost.
The `create full animation` action will create a picture sprite that cycles through all the sprite cells, from left to right, top to bottom.

`loops` controls how many times the animation is played. If `loops` is negative, the animation goes on forever. If `loops` is positive, the animation runs until the number of loops is achieved; then the sprite is deleted.
## Partial Animations
Instead of animating over all the sprite cells in the sheet, you can specify an area of cells that will be animated using the `create animation` action.
## Creating an animation
You can change an animation by using the `set animation` action.
Updates the sprite picture displayed on the sprite. This action should be called on sprites created with the `create sprite` action.
Gets the number of rows in sheet `id`.
Gets the number of columns in the sprite sheet `id`.
Animates the sprites cells. This action must be called before or after `board->evolve` is called when animations are used.
Clears any animation associated with `sprite`

Sets how the sprite should roll through sprite cells at a given rate. The cells are walked left to right over `duration` seconds. Indices start at 1. `loops` decides how many times the animation is played. If `loops` is negative, the animation plays forever. Make sure to call `evolve` in your `gameloop` if you plan to use this feature.
Declares a sprite sheet that can be used later on. `sheet id` should be a unique identifier that will be used later on to assign images to sprites.

Create a fresh animated sprite from the `sheet id` sprite sheet. The animation runs for `duration` seconds, `loops` times. If `loops` is negative, the animation loops forever. If `loops` is positive, the animation will stop and the sprite will be deleted. The sprite cells are enumerated left to right, top to bottom. Indices start at 1.
Gets a value indicating if the sprite is animated.

Create a fresh animated sprite from the `sheet id` sprite sheet. The animation runs for `duration` seconds, `loops` times over all the sprite cells in the sheet. If `loops` is negative, the animation loops forever. If `loops` is positive, the animation will stop and the sprite will be deleted. The sprite cells are enumerated left to right, top to bottom.
